name: 陳雅玫
objective: This is an introductory course aiming to familiarize students with basic concepts of translation, including qualifications of good translators, the procedure of translation, use of references & electronic tools and the idea of translation equivalence. Also, the relevance of contrastive studies between English and Chinese to translation will be introduced. A guided application of the linguistic knowledge to practical work will be provided, in the interest of assisting students in formulating suitable and appropriate translation strategies and techniques. This course is intended to prepare students for more specialized translation training.
schedule:
Week 1: course introduction
Week 2: lecture on “what makes a good translator?”; exercises
Week 3: oral report; lecture on: (1) procedure of translation;
(2)  references & electrical tools
Week 4: lecture on translation equivalence
Week 5: lecture on contrastive studies of lexicon & translation (1)
Week 6: lecture on contrastive studies of lexicon & translation (2)
Week 7: lecture on contrastive studies of verbs & translation
Week 8: lecture on contrastive studies of nouns and pronouns &  
        translation
Week 9: Mid-term
Week 10: lecture on contrastive studies of prepositions and articles
         & translation
Week 11: lecture on contrastive studies of adjectives and adverbs & 
         translation
Week 12: lecture on contrastive of conjunctions and negative 
         constructions & translation
Week 13: lecture on contrastive studies of word order & translation  
         (1)
Week 14: lecture on contrastive studies of word order & translation 
         (2)
Week 15: lecture on idioms & translation
Week 16: lecture on cultures & translation
Week 17: wrap up
Week 18: Final exam

Requirements & Rules:
1. Please turn off your cell phone during the two-hour class period.

2. Absence: Students are expected to attend the class ON TIME. 
   (1) Being late for more than TWENTY minutes equals one hour 
       unexcused absence. One hour UNEXCUSED absence results in 4  
       points deduction. 
   (2) For an absence to be excused, students need to submit 
       compelling evidence of the gravity or unforseeability of the
       event causing the absence within ONE WEEK. 
   (3) Students missing more than EIGHT hours unexcused will have a  
       fail.
   (4) Absence from a class is no excuse for not knowing the  
       assignment and what has been discussed in that class. There  
       will be NO MAKE-UP EXAM unless you have valid and official 
       reasons for absence BEFOREHAND.

3. Assignments: 
  (1) Translation assignments will be given periodically throughout
      the course. All translation assignments have to be typed. 
      Further details concerning the format will be provided in
      Week 3. 
  (2) Each assignment goes through the following stages: (a)  
      submission of the first draft by due date, (b) discussion of 
      assignment in class, and (c) submission of the second draft, 
      which will be evaluated. 
  (3) All assignments must be submitted via e-mail by 5PM SUNDAY. 
      For late assignments, 20% of the assignment mark will be 
      deducted each day. Assignments more than THREE days late will 
      not be accepted

4. Pre-readings: Students must complete the assigned pre-readings 
   prior to the class session. All articles covered by the pre-
   readings are included in the in-class quizzes and final exam.
